A typical employment policy clearly defines the path to employment for the next generation, answering questions including:

• Does the policy connect with lineal descendants only? What about spouses?
<br> • Who do we check out when we wish to get a position?
<br> • What education is necessary before we can work full time in the company?
<br> • The amount of years of outside work experience are essential before we can are available in fulltime?
<br> • Are able to we work directly for another relative?
<br> • How will our pay end up determined?
<br> • How will promotions be concluded?
<br> • What is the process for receiving performance feedback inside new position?
<br> • Can a member of family be terminated? If so, by what process?

The employment policy is important, but not sufficient to steer family employment in a confident direction.

The third component needed to navigate family employment issues can be a Code of Conduct to guide behavior on the job. The ownership group has tremendous power in guiding productive family behavior just by working together to forge a set of expectations to which kin can aspire. The Code of Carryout drives behavior by articulating the family's expectations regarding the following:

• How are we expected to perform on the job?

<br> • Precisely what our expectations for vacation, time off and work hours?
<br> • What will we do when we have a conflict with other family employees?
<br> • How will we talk about each other to partners, relatives and others?

Having worked together to determine the three components with integration, the family must then talk to non-family management about it's hopes regarding family employment. This is best done at a forum between the family shareholders and relevant essential non-family managers.

The other issue, family perks within a time of scarcity, justifies the family's attention. Assuring that family perks may not be impacting employee compensation structures negatively can be a start.
